Comment: Again with the centre game. Keeps my options open; the only pieces I am unable to move on my next move are rooks.

Keeping with the centre game. My queen comes out to complete the pawn trade to gain some tempo...
Keeping with the centre game. My queen comes out to complete the pawn trade to gain some tempo...
...but loses a little thanks to the QBP, which is now protected by the bishop. Still, she sits nicely on the 3rd rank...
...but loses a little thanks to the QBP, which is now protected by the bishop. Still, she sits nicely on the 3rd rank...
...and my opponent gets level on development with his knight...
...so I develop my own knight on the kingside to get back ahead on development...
...and he moves up the pawn that started in front of his developed knight, no doubt hoping to fianchetto his bishop...
...so I bring out my other knight onto the long dark diagonal...
...and he moves up the other knight's pawn, again possibly to fianchetto his other bishop...
...but I don't know why I moved my knight up there, other than to set up a fork on c7...
...and as the bishop attacks the knight, meaning that if I remove my piece, I could lose my bishop...
...I move up its pawn, hoping to fianchetto my own bishop...
...and we trade my knight for his bishop, leaving my bishop reasonably placed...
...and we trade my knight for his bishop, leaving my bishop reasonably placed...
...and he finally fianchettos his bishop...
...but why did I move up my kingside rook's pawn, when 10... Ng4 would lose a horizontal/vertical piece?
He obviously didn't see my mistake, castling kingside...
...and I give him another chance by also castling kingside...
...and he attacks my bishop with his pawn...
...forcing it to retreat to the only safe place...
...but yet again he fails to spot the opportunity to win my queen/rook...
...so I finally see the danger and move my rook out of harm's way...
